Fig. 1 Optimized structure of M/C2N (M=Cu, Co, Fe): (a) C2N; (b) Cu/C2N; (c) Co/C2N; (d) Fe/C2N. Fig 1 Fig. 2 The binding energy and metal cohesive energy of M/C2N (M=Cu, Co, Fe). Fig 2 Fig. 3 The charge differential density of C2N and Fe/C2N: (a) C2N; (b) Fe/C2N. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Optimized structure of M/C2N (M=Cu, Co, Fe) for CO2 adsorption: (a) Cu/C2N; (b) Co/C2N; (c) Fe/C2N. (d) The charge differential density of Cu/C2N for CO2 adsorption (isovaule=0.065 e/Å3). The yellow and blue areas indicate the electrons accumulation and depletion, respectively. Note: the number in brackets indicates the size of adsorption energy (eV). (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig 4 Fig. 5 Optimized structure of M/C2N (M=Cu, Co, Fe) for H2 adsorption: (a) Cu/C2N; (b) Co/C2N; (c) Fe/C2N. (d) The charge differential density of Cu/C2N for H2 adsorption (isovaule=0.065 e/Å3).The yellow and blue areas indicate the electrons accumulation and depletion, respectively. Note: the number in brackets indicates the size of adsorption energy (eV). (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig 5 Fig. 6 Three reaction paths of low-temperature RWGS. The red represents the redox mechanism, blue represents the carboxyl mechanism, and purple represents the formic acid mechanism, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig 6 Fig. 7 The energy barrier change of each step for low-temperature RWGS promoted by C2N and M/C2N (M=Cu, Co, Fe): (a) Redox mechanism; (b) carboxyl mechanism. Note: the small figure of picture b in the left corner is an enlarged view of the rate-determining step. Fig 7 Fig. 8 The side view and top view of the transition state involved in the redox mechanism and the carboxyl mechanism of low-temperature RWGS on Cu/C2N surface: (a) redox mechanism; (b) carboxyl mechanism. School of Life Science Huzhou University 759 East Erhuan Road Huzhou 313000 PR China The reaction path of low temperature reverse water gas reaction (RWGS) on M/C2N (M=Cu, Co, Fe) was studied by density functional theory (DFT). The results show that after doping, electrons transfer from M to C2N and gather directionally on the surface of C2N, which significantly changes the catalytic behavior of C2N. Because the increase of electronic activity reduces the reaction activation energy, it effectively promotes the RWGS on C2N at low temperature. We also found that the low-temperature RWGS on Cu/C2N and Co/C2N proceed according to the redox mechanism, while Fe/C2N tend to the carboxyl mechanism. Moreover, the energy barrier of rate-determining step in redox mechanism for Cu/C2N is the lowest, indicating that the low-temperature RWGS reaction is more likely to occur on this structure. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords C2N Low-temperature RWGS Transition metals doping Density functional theory (DFT) Carbon neutralization 1 Introduction In recent years, the continuous growth of energy demand has led to a large consumption of fossil fuels [1], increasing CO2 in the atmosphere, and the phenomenon of climate change and global warming has become increasingly urgent [2]. In order to protect the environment and limit the sharp rise of global temperature, the concept of carbon neutralization has been put forward all over the world [3–7]. How to effectively convert CO2 has become a key problem. Reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS): CO2 (g) + H2 (g) → CO (g) + H2O (g), is an important method for CO2 conversion, and the generated CO can be further converted into organics required, such as CH3OH and olefins [8–10]. At present, high temperature RWGS is widely used in industry, but its catalyst is easy to inactivate, high energy consumption and high cost, which is not conducive to the reaction [11,12]. Low-temperature RWGS has the advantages of low energy consumption and low requirements for the high-temperature thermal stability of the catalyst [13,14]. Thus, it is very important to find an effective catalyst to promote the conversion of CO2 by low-temperature RWGS. C2N is a two-dimensional material with the advantages of high stability and large specific surface area, which can provide a lot of adsorption and reaction sites when running catalysis [15]. Compared with traditional catalysts, the pores with six regularly spaced nitrogen lone pairs in the lining ring (6N-cavities) are extremely suitable for anchoring metallic nanoparticles and single atoms, acting as an “active support.” [16–18]. Recently, a kind of graphene-liked carbon-based material C2N was synthesized by bottom-up wet chemical reaction [19]. Monolayer C2N has attracted much attention because of its cavity structure. At present, it has been widely used in the fields of gas separation, seawater desalination and the preparation of new materials by cavity anchored metal [20–22]. It is found that the 6 N cavity of monolayer C2N has a natural active cavity compared with some metal oxides such as CeO2, but the charge distribution of C2N is uniform, the negative charge is enriched in the center of the cavity, and the positive charge is enriched on both sides, so that small molecules can not be well adsorbed. In recent years, single atom catalysts (SACs) have been widely used in the field of catalysis because of their high activity, high selectivity, high metal atom utilization and high stability [23,24]. By doping monatomic transition metals, the disadvantage of uniform charge distribution of C2N can be improved, and the charges can be directionally aggregated to better adsorb small molecules for related redox reactions. For example, Ma et al. calculated C2N doped with Cr and Mn through DFT and found that the material has strong catalytic activity for low-temperature CO oxidation reaction [25]. He et al. constructed a low-cost and high activity monatomic catalyst by embedding Fe into C2N based on the first principle, and discussed in detail the two-step mechanism of CO oxidation with O2 at low temperature [26]. At present, monatomic transition metals (Fe, Co, Cu, etc.) doped on C2N based catalysts have shown excellent catalytic activity and selectivity in hydrogen evolution reaction, oxygen evolution reaction, redox reaction, carbon dioxide reduction and catalytic organic reaction due to their unique structure [27–30]. Ma et al. studied the path of CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid on the monatomic catalyst Cu/C2N through the first principle [31]. The results show that the reaction tends to adsorb and dissociate H2 before reacting with CO2 on the surface of the catalyst. Yang et al. found through experiments that Cu doped catalyst can effectively catalyze RWGS at medium and low temperature, which provides the possibility of coupling RWGS reactor with syngas conversion reaction in industrial production [32]. Mahmood et al. synthesized Fe@C2N and found that it shows stable redox properties in alkaline and acidic media [33]. These findings provide strong support for the further development of commercial applications in different applications. Thus, in this paper, based on the first principle, we selected transition metal elements such as Cu, Co and Fe to construct transition metal M-doped C2N materials (recorded as M/C2N, M=Cu, Co, Fe). The structural stability, charge transfer, CO2 and H2 adsorption of M/C2N were studied, and three reaction mechanisms of low temperature RWGS on C2N and M/C2N were further discussed. 2 Calculation method and model parameters 2.1 Calculation method All the calculations in this paper were completed in the Dmol3 module, and the density functional theory (GGA-PW91) was adopted, which combines the Generalized gradient approximations and Perdew-Wang functional (PW91) [34–37]. The inner electrons of transition metals were replaced by effective nuclear potential pseudopotential (ECP), and the valence electron wave function is expanded by double numerical basis plus orbital polarization function (DNP). The DFT-D method of OBS dispersion correction was used to describe the van der Waals force between molecules [38]. The criterion of structural optimization was that the energy difference is less than 2 × 10−5 Ha, the atomic displacement is less than 5.0 × 10−4 nm, and the convergence of forces on each atom is 4.0 × 10−2 Ha/nm. The convergence criterion of self-consistent field (SCF) is 10−6 Ha. The Brillouin zone integration uses 4 × 4 × 1 of k points to optimize the structure. The vacuum layer was set at 15 Å to avoid non-physical interaction between periodic structures [39]. In this paper, structural optimization and vibration analysis are carried out for all calculation models to determine the vibration free virtual frequency. The bond length and energy of ten active species such as H*, CO*, O*, OH*, H2O*, CO2*, HOCO*, HCOO*, HCOOH*, CHO* after activation comply with the literature [40,41]. After that, the optimal configuration is selected, and the transition state search is carried out by using the complete first synchronization and second synchronization transformation (LSQ/QST) method. Through the frequency vibration analysis, it is determined that the transition state vibration frequency has only one virtual frequency. 2.2 Structural model of M/C2N (M=Cu, Co, Fe) Fig. 1 a is the structural model of C2N, which consists of a hexagon with 18 atoms, including 12 C atoms and 6 N atoms. The lattice parameter of C2N is a = b = 14.760 Å, in which the CN bond length is 1.350 Å, the CC bond length is 1.511 and 1.444 Å, the angle of CN-C is 120.320 °, and the diameter of cavity is 5.735 Å, which are similar to the results reported in the literature [42]. Considering that C2N can not well make charge aggregation promote low-temperature RWGS, three transition metal doped C2N two-dimensional materials (M/C2N) are constructed in this work, which are Cu doped C2N (Cu/C2N) in Fig. 1b, Co doped C2N (Co/C2N) in Fig. 1c and Fe doped C2N (Fe/C2N) in Fig. 1d. In order to describe the stability of the structure, the binding energy E b is defined as follows (Eq. (1)): (1) E b = E M + E undoped − E total where E total is the total energy after doping, E total is the total energy of the structure before doping, and E M is the energy of a single transition metal atom. Adsorption energy of small molecules on material surface ( E ads ) is expressed by Eq. (2): (2) E ads = E AB − E A − E SM where E AB is the total energy of the system after adsorption, E A is the total structural energy before adsorption, E SM is the energy carried by adsorbed small molecules. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Stability analysis and charge transfer of M/C2N (M=Cu, Co, Fe) Considering that M (Cu, Co, Fe) has different adsorption sites on C2N, we selected three sites above the N atom of 6 N cavity, above the C atom of 6 N cavity and in the center of 6 N cavity. The results show that all M atoms tend to be anchored at the hollow positions of 6 pyridine N atoms (as shown in Fig. 1). Fig. 2 is the calculated binding energy and metal cohesive energy of M/C2N (M=Cu, Co, Fe). Cohesive energy is a parameter to measure the force between aggregated substances. Generally speaking, the greater the cohesive energy, the easier the metal is to agglomerate and reduce the dispersion [43]. As shown in Fig. 2, in these three structures, the binding energy is greater than the cohesive energy, indicating that the metal will not agglomerate, so Cu/C2N, Co/C2N and Fe/C2N can exist stably. The binding energy of Cu/C2N is greater than that of Co/C2N and Fe/C2N, indicating that the stability of Cu/C2N is better than that of the other two materials. Comparing the charge transfer between undoped C2N and M (Cu, Co, Fe) doped C2N, the electrons are transferred from M to C2N. Taking Fe/C2N as an example, Fig. 3 shows the charge transfer diagram of undoped C2N and Fe/C2N. It is observed that after Fe doping, the active sites are transferred from 6 N cavity to Fe, from uniform charge distribution to directional centralized distribution. Thus, M metal is the active site of the two-dimensional material. 3.2 Adsorption of CO2 on M/C2N (M=Cu, Co, Fe) Fig. 4 a–c show the adsorption of CO2 by M/C2N (M=Cu, Co, Fe), which shows that CO2 is adsorbed above the doped metal. The adsorption of CO2 on Cu/C2N and Fe/C2N is O-terminal adsorption, and the distances of M-O are 2.236 Å and 2.200 Å, respectively. The bond angle of CO2 on Cu/C2N decreased by 2.182 ° and that on Fe/C2N decreased by 3.271 ° compared with that before adsorption. In Co/C2N, the adsorption of CO2 is C-terminal adsorption, the adsorption energy is −0.62 eV, the distance between Cu-C is 1.920 Å, and the bond angle of CO2 after adsorption is 147.540 ° (32.46 ° less than that before adsorption). The difference of adsorption energy implies that Cu/C2N has better adsorption capacity of CO2 (−0.86 eV) than Co/C2N and Fe/C2N. The specific data of CO2 adsorption by M/C2N (M=Cu, Co, Fe) are shown in Table 1 . Take Cu/C2N as an example (Fig. 4d) to illustrate the charge transfer of CO2 during M/C2N adsorption. Before CO2 adsorption, the charge of Cu atom is +0.385 e, while the nearest two N from Cu are −0.361 to −0.363 e. After adsorption, Cu charge is +0.401 e, which is 0.016 e higher than that before CO2 adsorption; The charges of the two N adjacent to Cu are −0.353 e and −0.345 e respectively, while the O in CO2 is closest to Cu and the charge is −0.287 e. During the adsorption process, the direction of electrons is from the catalyst surface to CO2 (the charge transfer of the other two materials is the same as that of Cu/C2N, shown in Table 1). The results of charge transfer show that metal are not only an electron donor but also a charge transfer bridge, which improves the ability of C2N material to adsorb CO2. 3.3 Adsorption of H2 on M/C2N (M=Cu, Co, Fe) Similar to CO2, H2 is also adsorbed on M atoms in M/C2N (M=Cu, Co, Fe) (Fig. 5 a–c). The bond lengths of adsorbed H2 were extended by 0.074 Å (Cu/C2N), 0.044 Å (Co/C2N) and 0.057 Å (Fe/C2N), respectively. The adsorption energies of H2 on Cu/C2N, Co/C2N and Fe/C2N are −0.94 eV, −0.90 eV and −0.92 eV, respectively (Table 2 ). In the process of H2 adsorption, the M atom in M/C2N (M=Cu, Co, Fe) also acts as an intermediate medium in electron migration. Taking Cu/C2N as an example (Fig. 5d), before doping, the charge of N atoms in 6 N cavity is −0.245 e. After C2N doped Cu and adsorbed H2, it was found that the charge of Cu was +0.114 e, and the charge of two H was 0.191 and 0.089 e respectively, while the nearest two N to Cu was −0.353 and −0.338 e. It indicates that during the adsorption process, the electron transferred from Cu to C2N continues to transfer to the adsorbed H2. In other words, after adsorption, H2 undertakes part of the ability to transfer electrons, so as to improve the ability of M/C2N catalyst to adsorb H2. 3.4 Reaction mechanism of low-temperature RWGS on M/C2N (M=Cu, Co, Fe) At present, for the reaction mechanism of low-temperature RWGS, it is generally considered that there are three reaction paths [44], as shown in Fig. 6 . Path 1 is a conventional redox mechanism, H2* and CO2* are dissociated; CO2* is desorbed after dissociation to directly produce CO*, while the O* dissociated by CO2* is combined with the H* dissociated by H2* to form OH*; OH* combines with another H* dissociated from H2* to form H2O*; Finally, H2O* is desorbed. Path 2 is the carboxyl mechanism, and the H* dissociated from CO2* to H2* generates HOCO*; HOCO* is dissociated, the dissociated CO* is desorbed, and the dissociated OH* is combined with another H* dissociated by H2* to form H2O*; Finally, H2O* is desorbed. Path 3 is the mechanism of formic acid, which contains two paths, I and II. The difference between the two paths lies in the dissociation of HCOOH*. In path I, CO2* and H* generate HCOO*, HCOO* and H* combine to form HCOOH*, and the dissociated CO* and H2O* are desorbed; In path II, HCOOH* is dissociated into CHO* and OH*, CHO* is further dissociated to form CO* and H*, and H* is combined with OH* to form H2O*. The 6 N cavity contained in C2N is a good active site, which is conducive to the activation of H2 [45]. This step is the start-up step of low-temperature RWGS and plays a key role in the whole reaction process. However, the negative charge in the 6 N cavity of C2N is evenly distributed in the center, which will hinder the reaction of H2, which needs positive charge for oxidation reaction (Fig. S1). However, after the introduction of transition metal atoms, as shown in Fig. 3, the total negative charge of C2N cavity is reduced compared with that without doping, which is conducive to the reaction. This is well reflected in the activation energy barrier and reaction energy of each elementary reaction on each catalyst (Table 3 ). Comparing the energy barrier data of the low-temperature RWGS mechanism catalyzed by the three catalysts, it is found that Cu/C2N and Co/C2N prefer redox mechanism and carbonyl mechanism (Fig. 7 ), while formic acid mechanism is difficult to carry out (the energy barrier of the rate-determining step is as high as 5.231 and 5.598 eV, which is much larger than that of the first two paths). In the redox mechanism of Cu/C2N, the state of each step is shown in Fig. 8 a. Firstly, H2* adsorbed on Cu begins to dissociate, one H* is still adsorbed on Cu, and the other H* is combined with N close to Cu atom in 6 N cavity. This step requires endothermic 0.188 eV and reaction energy barrier E a =0.481 eV. CO2* dissociates to form CO* and O*, O* combines with the N opposite to Cu in 6 N cavity, the reaction energy barrier is 0.073, and 0.038 eV heat is released. The combination of O* and H* to form OH* is the rate-determining step of Cu/C2N redox mechanism, and the reaction energy barrier is E a =0.518 eV. In the process of forming OH* from O* to H*, the energy barrier is large due to the large binding energy between H* and N. Finally, OH* bound to Cu and another H* generate H2O*, endothermic 0.010 eV, and reaction energy barrier E a =0.032 eV. The carboxyl mechanism is mainly divided into four elementary reactions. The first step (H2*→H*+H*) and the last step (OH*+ H*→H2O*+*) are consistent with the redox mechanism. Thus, the second step (CO2*+H*→HOCO*+*) and the third step (HOCO*→OH*+ CO*) are mainly discussed (Fig. 8b). In the second step, CO2* and H* are adsorbed on Cu (the binding energy is −3.64 eV), and the generated HOCO* is also above Cu, the energy barrier of that elementary reaction is E a =1.914 eV, releasing 0.822 eV. After that, HOCO* is dissociated to OH* and CO*. Because the CO bond is not easy to break, it needs to cross the energy barrier of 1.937 eV, thus this step is also a rate-determining step of carboxyl mechanism for Cu/C2N. In the case of Co/C2N, the energy barrier of the three paths is formic acid mechanism (5.598 eV) > carboxyl mechanism (2.795 eV) > redox mechanism (1.586 eV). Thus, the low-temperature RWGS on Co/C2N is also consistent with Cu/C2N and tends to redox mechanism. Moreover, since the energy barrier of the reaction on Co/C2N is larger than that of Cu/C2N (0.518 eV), the reaction is less likely to occur on Co/C2N. While, the mechanism of RWGS on Fe/C2N is quite different from Cu/C2N to Co/C2N. For Fe/C2N, the reaction is more inclined to the carboxyl mechanism ( E a =1.738 eV), while the redox mechanism ( E a =6.178 eV) and formic acid mechanism ( E a =4.354 eV) are difficult to carry out. Fig. 9 shows the side and top views of transition states involved in redox mechanism and carboxyl mechanism of low-temperature RWGS on Fe/C2N surface. In the carboxyl mechanism (Fig. 9b), H2* is dissociated after being adsorbed on Fe/C2N. The energy barrier required for the reaction is E a =0.197 eV, endothermic 0.030 eV. CO2* adsorbed on Fe interacts with H* adsorbed in 6 N cavity to form HOCO*, and the energy barrier required for this step is E a =1.182 eV, releasing heat of 0.185 eV. HOCO* is dissociated to form CO* and OH* on Fe. This process is the rate-determining step of carboxyl mechanism, and the reaction energy barrier is E a =1.738 eV. Finally, the OH* dissociated from CO2* reacts with H* to form H2O*. In conclusion, compared with pristine C2N, the energy barriers of the corresponding rate-determining steps of the three metal doped C2N materials are reduced, which can significantly promote the low-temperature RWGS. Combined with the above comparison of adsorption energy, charge transfer and energy barrier in the three reaction paths, Cu/C2N maybe the most potential catalyst for low-temperature RWGS. 4 Conclusion In this paper, the transition metal M (Cu, Co, Fe) doped C2N two-dimensional material is constructed for solving the problem that negative charge enrichment in 6 N cavity of C2N is not conducive to H2 oxidation reaction. The reaction paths of low temperature RWGS on four materials (C2N, M/C2N) were studied. The C2N of three doped metals was easier to react than the pristine C2N. It shows that C2N doped with transition metals Cu, Co and Fe can significantly improve the ability to catalyze RWGS at low temperature, and has the application prospect as the reaction catalyst. And the energy barrier of rate-determining step for Cu/C2N is the lowest, which maybe the most potential catalyst for low-temperature RWGS. It is found that the low-temperature RWGS on Cu/C2N and Co/C2N proceed according to the redox mechanism, and the rate-determining step is O*+H*→OH*+*; Fe/C2N tends to carboxyl mechanism, and the rate-determining step is HOCO*→OH*+ CO*. The current study predicts a good application prospect of Cu/C2N for low temperature RWGS and provides inspiration for the further development of two-dimensional carbon nitride materials for low temperature RWGS. coredata.dc:description: The reaction path of low temperature reverse water gas reaction (RWGS) on M/C2N (M=Cu, Co, Fe) was studied by density functional theory (DFT). The results show that after doping, electrons transfer from M to C2N and gather directionally on the surface of C2N, which significantly changes the catalytic behavior of C2N. Because the increase of electronic activity reduces the reaction activation energy, it effectively promotes the RWGS on C2N at low temperature. We also found that the low-temperature RWGS on Cu/C2N and Co/C2N proceed according to the redox mechanism, while Fe/C2N tend to the carboxyl mechanism. Moreover, the energy barrier of rate-determining step in redox mechanism for Cu/C2N is the lowest, indicating that the low-temperature RWGS reaction is more likely to occur on this structure.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical study on low temperature reverse water gas shift (RWGS) mechanism on monatomic transition metal M doped C2N catalyst (M=Cu, Co, Fe)
